Testability
We have lots of different abstractions for *similar* input
Reacts differently to the same input depending on state
WHAT IS A FINITE STATE MACHINE?
WHAT IS A fINITE STATE MACHINE?
WHAT IS A fINITE STATE MACHINE?

A computational abstraction that:
Has a finite number of states in which it can exist
WHAT IS A fINITE STATE MACHINE?

A computational abstraction that:
Has a finite number of states in which it can exist
Can only be in one state at any time
WHAT IS A fINITE STATE MACHINE?

A computational abstraction that:
Has a finite number of states in which it can exist
Can only be in one state at any time
Accepts input
WHAT IS A fINITE STATE MACHINE?

A computational abstraction that:
Has a finite number of states in which it can exist
Can only be in one state at any time
Accepts input
Can produce output determined by state &/or input
WHAT IS A fINITE STATE MACHINE?

A computational abstraction that:
Has a finite number of states in which it can exist
Can only be in one state at any time
Accepts input
Can produce output determined by state &/or input
Can transition from one state to another*
THAT WAS A LOT OF TEXT ON One SCREEN

GooD!
Here’s some Fine Print on State machines

Acceptor
Transducer
Moore machine - output depends on state (entry actions)
Mealy machine - output depends on state and input

Deterministic - only one transition possible for each input
Non-deterministic - zero or more transitions possible from an input

Deterministic - only one transition possible for each input
Non-deterministic - zero or more transitions possible from an input
States are organized into a ‘states’ object on the FSM
States are organized into a ‘states’ object on the FSMeach Object property is a state

States are organized into a ‘states’ object on the FSMeach Object property is a state 
each state object’s members are functions* that respond to input

States are organized into a ‘states’ object on the FSMeach Object property is a state 
each state object’s members are functions* that respond to inputcalling “transition(stateName)” changes state
FSM maps input to matching handler name: “handle(inputName, args*)”
FSM maps input to matching handler name: “handle(inputName, args*)”“_onEnter” & “_onExit” & “*”
FSM maps input to matching handler name: “handle(inputName, args*)”“_onEnter” & “_onExit” & “*” “deferUntilTransition([stateName])”
FSM maps input to matching handler name: “handle(inputName, args*)”“_onEnter” & “_onExit” & “*” “deferUntilTransition([stateName])”“deferUntilNextHandler()”

FSM maps input to matching handler name: “handle(inputName, args*)”“_onEnter” & “_onExit” & “*” “deferUntilTransition([stateName])”“deferUntilNextHandler()”
Built-in Event Emitter
*Sigh*...so much API info... what if I need to blink?

how does it help manage Connectivity state?

Online
Offline (the user said so!)
Disconnected (Oops, no connection)

Online
Offline (the user said so!)
Disconnected (Oops, no connection)
Probing (detecting if we’re online)
Wait...What happened to the HTTP BEHAVIOR?

FSMS Working Together: 
powerful way to manage & isolate complexity

https://github.com/a2labs/machina.promise

PROS
extremely versatile
Lends Well to good separation of concerns
Great for long-running async workflows
expressive

CONS
Modeling Complex/Hierarchical FSMs is “hard”
Less familiar pattern (for many)

notes.slide-15:
What abstractions - if any - do you use to tackle these sorts of problems?
These are just examples of longer-running async workflows... we’re going to pick one and use it as the guinea pig example....
notes.slide-22:
this kind of stuff, when not structured/abstracted ends up (at best) being littered procedurally all over the place.
the more it’s littered, the greater the surface area of risk for crazy bugs due to invalid/unknown state, etc.
notes.slide-30: by Testability -> is the sole means of triggering a state change tightly coupled to the implementation (DOM)?
notes.slide-16: let’s look at some of the tools available to detect connectivity state, etc.
notes.slide-24: UNKNOWN, ETHERNET, WIFI,CELL_2G, CELL_3G, CELL_4G, CELL, NONE
notes.slide-31: by Testability -> is the sole means of triggering a state change tightly coupled to the implementation (DOM)?
notes.slide-32: With Current browser APIs we have LOTS of different abstractions for similar kinds of input, all of which fall short. It’s like a bit of rat poison sprinkled into your sugar. just enough to make you sick after you think it’s sweet enough for your tastes...
notes.slide-25:
assuming we have some kind of app object.....
if that app object is an event emitter and other components can listen, great.
But it doesn’t solve everything AT ALL
notes.slide-34: you might recognize what this is *almost*
notes.slide-42: We are talking about FSMs from a higher level than implementations like parsers, hardware-oriented FSMs, etc.
notes.slide-28: by Testability -> is the sole means of triggering a state change tightly coupled to the implementation (DOM)?

notes.slide-50:
Acceptor FSMs typically produce bool (yes/no) response to input. sequence detection is a good example. all states are said to be accepting or not. when finished, if in accepted state - input is accepted
Transducer FSMs produce output based on the input and/or state.  Moore FSMs produce output as a result of entering a state, 
where Mealy’s output is dependent on state and input.
BEFORE TRANSITION -> WHO USES PROMISES/DEFERREDS??
